Situation1: They share their work challenges and personal concerns after noticing their spouse seems worried.
Expectation2: Wash and condition clients' hair before cutting or styling
Situation2: The hair is a bit sweaty after a gym session and looks greasy.
Story: I glanced at the clock, knowing my next client would arrive any minute. My hands were still damp from cleaning up the last station when my spouse walked in, eyes clouded with worry. I could tell something was weighing on them, and I remembered our promise to always talk things through, to never let concerns fester. But just as I opened my mouth to ask what was wrong, my client entered, hair matted and greasy from a workout, clearly expecting the full wash and condition before her cut. I felt the pressure mounting—my spouse needed me to listen, to be present, but my client expected my undivided attention and professional care. My heart pounded as I tried to balance the urge to comfort my partner with the obligation to provide the best service to my client. I could feel the tension rising inside me, torn between being the supportive spouse and the attentive hairdresser, knowing I couldn’t fully be both at the same time.
